captions.text: Do you know my friend Nick Stanatopolous?

- So just because I'm
Greek, I have to know
every other Greek person in LA?

BuzzFeed presents:
7 Things Greek-Americans Know to be True

- No. Look, I'm sorry, you
probably don't know Nick.
- Of course I know Nick. He's my cousin.
Shouting is a Form of Communication
- Do not even tell me it's George.

- To Sullivan's. He's
taking me to Sullivan's.

- We're excited. I'm
going on a date tonight.

- So, I saw you with Mike
yesterday. He's cute.
- You touch him I'll cut your throat.
our approach for video across the board.

We are gonna start
building a team approach,

so you have to have everything
approved by three people.
- What are we drinking here, huh?

- Oh no no no, that's not
for you! That's not for you!
- Uh. That tastes like a licorice fire.

title: 7 Things Greek Americans Know To Be True

comments.author: Nebras Salheb

comments.text:
I am Greek and Armenian myself and I know nothing of my culture. I was 
adopted by a Mexican family. I feel left out because I do not know any of 
the jokes and references made in this video. I met a full Armenian girl 
that I have a class with and she's taught me how to say yes and no in 
Armenian. It's just amazing, life, because if I were to stay with my 
biological parents or be adopted by parents of my culture, my life would 
probably a whole lot different. ﻿

comments.text:
I've been to Greece a couple of times. So:
1) "Shouting". Sometimes they do shout, but no more than Spaniards or 
Italians.
2) "Things escalate quickly". Guess so.
3) "Change is never welcome". Nonsense.
4) and 5) What?!
6) Who the hell is John Stamos?
7) Greeks do indeed drink a lot of ouzo. But they also drink wine 
(excellent), beer, and other hard liquors like tsipouro.﻿
